text.title: part11_John Reed on Orwell, God, self-destruction and the future of writing
text.p:
JR :
I do n't really think of myself as a born-again , and they of course insist on later baptism . I do n't know . I 'm sort of currently leaning towards the
Baptist church
.

JR :
Maybe . I have a lot of Southern --

p.hi: DS : They 're one of the least intolerant .

text.p:
JR :
Well , that 's interesting . I do n't know ; I have n't decided --

p.hi: DS : I went through a Southern Baptist phase when I lived in Georgia .
DS : Yeah , yeah . The Southern Baptist convention is probably the most conservative out there .

text.head: On politics

p.hi:
DS : If you were forced to choose , which war would you prefer to fight in ,
Iraq
or
Afghanistan
?

text.p:
JR :
Which one would I rather fight in ? Well , for whom ?

p.hi: DS : On the side of the United States .

text.p:
JR :
Iraq or Afghanistan ... God , that 's tough man . I think Afghanistan .

JR :
Well , at least we had an endgame .

JR :
I think Hillary . My reasoning is completely ridiculous : I distrust men who are that skinny . You and I are both lean , but if I told you , you 've got to go take this stump out to the backyard , and I gave you an axe , I 'd be pretty confident you could do it . Obama does n't look like he could do it to me . [ both laugh ] There 's something about that I mistrust .

p.hi: DS : If you remain that lean on the campaign trail , when they 're having all those --

text.p:
JR :
There 's something about it I distrust , a guy who ca n't lift a hammer .
text.head: On self-destruction and survival

p.hi: DS : How would you choose to die ?

text.p:
JR :
How would I choose to die ? I do n't know . Most men stop being afraid of dying . Then , when they have kids , suddenly they 're afraid of it again . But not for themselves , for their kids . So I do n't really care , just as long as my kids are provided for .

p.hi: DS : You think that most men , pre-parenthood , lose their sense of mortality and their fear of it ?

text.p:
JR :
I think you just get tired of being afraid of it .

p.hi: DS : Were you ever afraid of it ?

text.p:
JR :
Yeah , I was afraid of it in my early twenties ; and as a kid , I just remember being really , really afraid of dying , and it being incomprehensible and depressing .

p.hi: DS : Did that affect your behavior ?

text.p:
JR :
Well , my daughter , too . We had a lizard die , and that was a big deal . She was asking these questions , " Is it gonna be another lizard ? " You know , she has all of these --

JR :
Yeah , she has a lot of really valid questions . I do n't know ; I also do n't feel that we understand everything . For all the people who praise Shakespeare , Shakespeare is still really quite extraordinary . The sense that I have of Shakespeare is he does understand that on some level , we as human beings , our bodies , are like the top of an iceberg that you can see . Then there 's all this other stuff under the water that you ca n't see . That 's my feeling about it . I 'm not that afraid of it anymore because I feel like there 's all this other stuff under the water . But it does worry me --
